_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program  Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP)  Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, TGC Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 TGC Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that TGC Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                    | Process Chemical                    | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration    Anhydrous Ammonia               41,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligatio

ns as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

1.2.1 Facility Overview

TGC Cold Storage operates a commercial cold storage plant for a variety of nuts and vegetables in Bakersfield, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:
(9) Rooms
(4) Precool rooms
(5) Hallways
(2) Liquid recirculators
(1) Palletize room
(1) Hydro-cooler

1.2.2 Facility Location

TGC Cold Storage is located at 16350 Driver Rd, Bakersfield, CA 93308. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 36.495230, -119.469466. The facility is located immediately west of state highway 99 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.
According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in a special flood hazard area. The elevation of the machinery room was designed with the flood hazards in mind.

TGC Cold Storage is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that faults within close proximity are not considered high risk:
New Hope fault - <150 Years
Premier fault - <150 Years
New Hope fault - <1,600,000 Years
Poso Creek fault - <1,600,000 Years

The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that TGC Cold Storage had a 2-5% chance of experiencing potentially minor-damage due to ground shaking in 2018.

1.2.3 Description of Covered Process

The evaporators in the Hydrocooler and Precool Rooms are supplied from flooded accumulators while air-cooling evaporators in Rooms 1-9  and the hallways are supplied by recirculators. As such, the system is con

figured for both flooded and pumped overfeed operation.
Most control valve groups are located inside the building. The refrigeration machinery is contained within the machinery areas. A partial list of system components includes: 

Outdoor Machinery Area
(4) Screw compressors
(4) Oil separators
(2) High pressure receivers
(1) Liquid transfer vessel
(1) Liquid recirculator
(6) Evaporative condensers 
North Recirculator Area
(1) Liquid recirculator
(1) Drop leg vessel
(1) Oil pot 
Hydrocooler
(1) Accumulator
(4) Water-cooled evaporators (bare coils)

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)

(10) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)

Palletize Room
(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended) 
Room 1
(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)

Room 7

Room 9

Precool 1

Precool 3 North

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Process Classification
The ammonia refrigeration system at TGC Cold Storage consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at TGC Cold Storage is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical S

pecific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

TGC Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the TGC Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

TGC Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

TGC Cold Storages emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
California Emergency Action Plan  Title 8 CCR §3220
Federal Emergency Action Plan - Title 29 CFR §1910.38 
California Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER)  Title 8 CCR Title 8 §5192(q)
Federal Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER)  Title 29 CFR §1910.120(q)

Strategically, we will

respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

TGC Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, TGC Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved TGC Cold Storages ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that TGC Cold Storages management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

TGC Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, TGC Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, TGC Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for TGC Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the
RMP-PSM program TGC Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
